												WARNING! THIS GAME CAN BE DIFFICULT!But, AH! The memories! :DThe protagonist of this memorable tale is named Abe. A Mudokon who was born a slave and works for RuptureFarms, a meat processing factory. One day Abe discovers that he and his kind are to be sent to the slaughterhouse. Not only that, they will soon become the "new & tasty" delicasy on the menu! He decides that he better make a break from the Glukkons who hold him captive and decides to rescue as many of his fellow Mudokons as he can along the way.And so, his unexpected quest begins! There are a total of 99 Mudokons that await liberation. Some of them you really have to look for and there are a bunch of hidden rooms to find them in. Abe must rescue at least 50 of his kinfolk in order to survive the games ending. At times it can be a demanding task with little or no room for mistake to succeed. The game offers a very steep learning curve and rewards you with silly characters, enjoyable scenery, great music (which can and will become annoying when you get stuck), comical yet very well done cutscenes and most importantly, you will experience a fun and satisfying time overall.PROS:+ A hilariously alluring story line that draws from a serious matter concerning slavery+ Fantastic character design and visual concepts+ Nice graphics and animations (originally released in 1997 and it still looks pretty good)+ Lots of secret rooms to discover+ Innovative gameplay that will fulfill your desires for a real challengeCONS:- The save feature is not what you'd hope for in a game this grueling (you must reach checkpoints which means you better look forward to replaying strenuous parts over and over, again and again... and again)- There is no incentive for saving all 99 Mudokons (except for a video that was only featured in the original Playstation version)- I broke at least one Playstation controller during a rage quit I remember all the excitement of 3D gaming with the PS1 and still choosing to suffer this brutal sidescrolling platformer in 2D because the game is just so intriguingly awesome. One that still stands compelling to this day. I'd definitely recommend it. A replay even, for nostalgic purposes at least, if you're a gamer of the day. And it's absolutely worth a "taste" if Mudokon is new to you!My personal rating: 8.5/10

												Easily a contender for my favorite game of all time. The story is a fantastic example of handling serious issues without being preachy, never forgetting to be fun and amusing. The blend of 2D stealth, puzzling and platforming gameplay is just about perfect, and challenging without being excessively punishing. The controls are similar to Tomb Raider, in that they are very precise; they follow strict rules, and your every move is calculable. The visuals are also pushed to the absolute limits of the PlayStation; you won't find any polygons in this one, and the cutscene-to-gameplay transitions are so seamless it's uncanny.The only reasonable gripe I can see people having with it is the difficulty. The game is not without its trial and error, for sure, and this game lacks the quicksave option of Exoddus. I've heard some describe its challenge as ranging from "unreasonable" to "impossible." On the front of the old PlayStation jewel case, you'll even see it blantantly say it has "inexplicably challenging gameplay," and all you have to deal with that is a functional brain and infinite lives (you'll need them.) Oh, and magical powers. The game might have "forgotten" to tell you that until the third level... whoops. Yes, all this game teaches you are the basics. There isn't much hand-holding, and you will likely get the bad ending on your first playthrough. However, you will get a chance to fix that, starting from the beginning of the final level. This was certainly a deliberate design decision. If you have reservations about the difficulty of this game, play Exoddus first, for the quicksave, and an even larger game.

												While the game's remake is already available on Steam (under the title New 'N' Tasty) you can still pick up the original Oddworld game which was released back in 1997 - almost 20 years ago! This was what started the Oddworld franchise that since that year has seen several sequels.These games are all about Abe, the titular character, who is a Mudokon slave being captive in a factory. Initially just a worker, but later labelled as "meat to be processed", Abe sets out to escape from his captors and also to free his fellow Mudokons in the process. The game's first cutscene (which is pretty long considering it is an old game) summarises the story very well and we can quickly understand what's ahead of us.This is a 2D platformer, so we go from screen to screen and every new "room" represents a new challenge. We have patrolling enemies as well as traps and of course members of the Mudokon race who we need to rescue. We can issue some basic commands to them to make sure they follow us - this part where you communicate with the others can be hilarious. Do note that this is one of those games where one mistake can lead to certain death. Checkpoints are regularly placed, though, so at least the game is not punishing you for being a little careless from time to time. One particularly interesting thing is how you can make other Mudokons die if you are not careful - the game does not take you back to the last checkpoint so you may think this is not a problem. Truth is, the number of saved Mudokons determines the ending of the game - you can either get the Good or the Bad ending.The gameplay is really good - Abe can do a lot of things in terms of movement and activating various mechanisms throughout the factory. Sections tend to get more and more difficult but Oddworld offers an acceptable learning curve here. I haven't tried the remake so I do not know how good a job they did - still, if you like old games or you are, just like myself, someone having played this back in the '90s do give it a try once more!

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Do you love platformers? Like games with lots of secrets? Need a challenge? Then Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is the game for you. Abe's Oddysee is a 2D sidescrolling cinematic platformer/puzzle game (phew!) with some interesting twists. Story: You are Abe, a mudokon who works on Rupture Farms. Abe lives a great life, despite being a slave. One day, while roaming the area, Abe finds that Glukkons (the scumbag rich species of Oddworld) want to turn mudokons into food. Abe, finding that out, decides that the best thing to do is save the 99 mudokons in Rupture Farms. Your journey won't be easy, because deadly enemies are almost everywhere.Gameplay: As I said before, this is a 2D platformer. The game is divided in screens (fixed camera, i,e., go to the right edge of the screen and it moves to the next camera/play area). This system gives the player a sense of suspense, because you never know what's in the next screen. One of the powers Abe has is possessing his enemies. Press the button, wait some seconds, you are controlling the enemy. You can do almost everything with him (kill him, kill other enemies, pull levers, fall off a cliff, you name it!) and it's an helpful power to finish your journey. There is a basic speaking system called GameSpeak that allows to control other mudokons using basic sentences (Hi!, Follow me, wait and even farting!). Mudokons must be moved using this system and taken to the nearest bird portal. Just chant and voila! The portal opens and they're saved! (:D) Unless... they trip on a mine. ( :( ) The only problem this game has in terms of gameplay is that checkpoints are infrequent and sometimes you will have to do same thing again and again only to die in the same place.Graphics: Even though some screens look 3D, they are actually pre-rendered. The environments are beautiful and varied.Sound: The soundtrack adds to the atmosphere, and the sound effects are pretty good.Final thoughts: Despite the somewhat dated graphics, Oddworld is an amazing game. 												One of the greatest platformers of all time. The cinematic style of this game has always astounded me even to this day, the games visual style still holds up today which is good for a playstation one era game. From the dark, dirty factories of Rupture farms to the vast plains of Scrabania, this game is an absoloute pleasure to look at no matter where you go.The gameplay is another one of this games strongpoints. The game focuses around controlling Abe, trying to escape Rupture Farms and save his Mudokon brothers from slavery by the Glukkons. The gameplay focuses around avoiding your adverseries by any means necessary, as Abe doesnt have a way to attack but that is where possesion comes in.The controls are amazingly responsive, no real delay or anything which is an essential requirement for a sidescrolling platfromer of this type and Oddwolrd Inhabitants hit the nail on the head with this one. Abe controls just how he should, your main controls are the usual things such as running, sneaking jumping etc. The tone of the game is also fantastic. The game has a dark overtone through the whole experience, showing how Oddworld is changing and not in a good way. But the game is sort of lightened up with the characters that are presented to us throughout the full game. All the characters are likable in this game in their own way. The Sligs, The Glukkons, The Mudokons and especially Abe himself.Oddworld Inhabitants managed to create a character that was relatable in his own way, a character that was innocent enough but has been dropped into a situation that is so much bigger than he is. Oddworld Inhabitants have crafted a masterpiece here and i would recommend this game to anybody who loves platformers, action games or even stealth games.My only complaints have to be the checkpoint system is irritating, with checkpoints being very scarce and this game being very unforgiving with one hit deaths, learning puzzles can be rather difficult. Also not being able to call upon more than one Mudokon at once is kind of annoying. Luckily both of these issues have been fixed in the sequal.Abe's Oddysee still holds up today and is still one of my favourite games to date and a fantastic addition to the platforming genre. 8/10

												Never been a PS man myself, making this playthrough of Oddworld my first. Judging from what I've read, I think our situation here is a terrible port of an excellent game.The positives:-Interesting and thought-provoking puzzles-While meager, a fun world, sense of humor and plot-Cool art design, yoThe negatives:-Abysmal controls. Controlling Abe as he runs, jumps, walks slowly, rolls, mounts creatures and communicates with other characters is so blocky and obtuse to the point of aggravation. I know exactly what I want Abe to do. Translating that to the mechanics of the controls was excrutiating.-Frame rate in the cut scenes (excellent for the 90's!) is bested by old Gumby claymation. I can hardly tell what's going on in cutscenes with all the tearing.-Saving system is unclear. I can save at any point, but there's no telling where I will end up when I load a file. I may end up seven zones back from where I left off. I can lose up to half an hour of progress thanks to inaccurate saving.-Several times I loaded save files without Abe. I was stuck on a screen with no playable character. Rebooting the game fixed this but geez.-For the love of God why isn't there any controller support for Oddworld? This is killer on my hands trying to play this on my laptop keyboard! Why would a game designed for a controller not receive controller functionality during its port?-This game caused one of my laptops to crash whenever I tried loading it.I don't recommend this particular port. 												oddworld abe's oddysee is one of the greatest games ever created on the PS1 console. the cut scenes are amazing (even for the 90's these are pretty high class videos)GAMEPLAY-this games plays really well, the controls are amazing on keyboard, albeit a tad confusing. BUT not to worry, if you have a playstation game pad for the PC you can hook it up and play this game to your hearts content ... well ... you could do it already if you have a keyboard, but this game is made with a controller in mind so it would only improve on this already fantastic game. not to mention how you save game, just pause and save and you're done ... come back when you've decided you won't rage quit over how challenging the game is ... forgot to mention that actually. This game is incredibly unforgiving. one wrong move and "BOOM" ... you're blue paste gets splattered all over the screen, and you're left to think about what would happen to your green comrades if you could not re-spawn ... a banjo kazooie 'quit game ending if you will.it doesn't do that, i'm just saying thinking about it is weird ... what if they all get eaten and they sell your organs for dog food, humanity goes into a downward spiral as events you couldn't stop, happen. The sequels always end with the sad ending, and you're no where to be seen because you died 2 games ago, nobody even knows your name anymore. As a slag (animal) begins to munch on your tinned mudoken fingers and eyeballs, the last sentient part of you is converted into fecal matter and your race DIES ... all because you took one step to the right and got crushed by a barrel of meat ... but i digressSTORY-the story to this game is essentially one giant Eco friendly metaphor for our own industrial prowess ... but it is so subtle/just plain ignorable that it will not rest on your conscience at all. basically you're an actual "skrub" worker in the biggest meat factory on odd-world, your bosses want to kill and sell your race to (possibly) unwary, cannibalistic consumers (it's never specified who actually buys all this food). you get found out, chase scene happens, voodoo hoodoo guy with funny mask gives you powers, and you basically take off from there. the story is a lot more in-depth than that but, meh. it would spoil a lot of the lot to go into full detail (I'M DOING THIS FOR YOU, THE PURCHASER OF THIS FINE PRODUCT! DON'T HATE ME!)GRAPHICS-It's a ps1 game, so you can expect some ... aging, to take place. it's a side scroller from the 90's so its 32 bit graphic style will always hold up pretty well (if you're a forgiving sort of person who enjoys game play over graphics). it's not the worst game you will ever see in your life ... it definitely gives some 3D games i know of a run for there money.OVERALL-i would definitely recommend that you buy this game, as a matter of fact, just buy the entire Oddbox bundle. you get all the Odd-world games for £6.99 (when not on sale). that is a steal for anyone's library as they are all definitely worth purchasing. strangers wrath although not as popular as other Odd-world title is definitely commendable for a referral as well.

Posted: May 10, 2016
												I remember buying this game back when it was released for the PlayStation 1. As far as I remember, it was a popular release and it received many positive reviews by the major publications of the time. I was excited to buy it but as soon as I began playing it, I remember being disappointed. I can't remember whether or not I beat it back then but chances are high that I got bored and quit playing just as I did now.Despite what the multitude of nostalgic, rabid and headstrong fans say, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee  didn't age well at all from what was already a mediocre effort to begin with. While the character design is interesting and charming, everything else is quite flawed. The background graphics and animations are average to below average, the music is nearly non-existent, the sound effects can get borderline annoying at times, and worst of all, the controls are extremely unresponsive, sluggish and awkward. Getting Abe to perform the most basic of platforming moves such as seamlessly running, stopping, climbing on a ledge and then sneaking is painful and inadequate. Controlling Abe feels very much delayed and as if the movements were restricted in some way. The puzzles and rooms are designed competently for the most part but when you have to deal with the game's awful controls, solving each screen is too aggravating and devoid of any fun whatsoever. The gameplay revolves around traversing the game world one screen at a time. Even though not every screen presents the player with a puzzle or a situation that needs his or her attention, there is still the need to advance through each screen individually and with a slight pause between each transition. Deaths come often and the player will be forced to repeatedly wait through a lengthy death and restart animation that takes about five seconds to complete. The save system is based on checkpoints, so if the player dies several screens beyond the last checkpoint, every screen from the checkpoint to the point of death will need to be redone as many times as it takes until you reach the next checkpoint. Without mentioning any spoilers, it is encouraged that there is at least one additional playthrough after you beat the game once. In relation to this, one of the worst design choices in the game presents itself. The goal is to rescue slaves. Unfortunately for the player, many of the slaves are hidden away in secret areas that are absolutely not easy to find. Thanks to this design decision, this means the player will fail at the goal the game has set to be accomplished.It's surprising to me how much love Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee has garnered through the years. It has far too many flaws to be enjoyed and it's way too annoying to be played to completion. This game could easily have been so much better than it actually is.Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is mediocre.

												I don't know what to make of this game. The game has some really good puzzles to get through but it is at the same time it is so infuriating to get through.When the game sets itself into small micro levels (such as the trails or zulag rooms) then the game is fun to get through where it gives you a decent checkpoint and a set of objectvies to complete to get through the area. Where you can easily try and complete the puzzles put before you. The limitations of the area which you need to transcend lets the game to florish.Unfortnately the game falls apart in the more larger levels. This mainly down to the extremly poor checkpoint system. The checkpointing system is too sparse and any bonus you do will not create a new checkpoint after completion so you end having to re do any bonus area if you die and this can make sections last alot longer then needed and it becomes infurtiating that you have to constantly have to recomplete large sections of the game to proceed.Another problem is the hit detection and platforming sections of the game. When sections of the game demand precise platform is where the worst parts of the game shows up. You can be hurt by jumping obstacles by just standing on the edge of the platform which is extremly annoying considering the one hit kills in this game. The game also demands extremly precise platforming that you can easily miss the jump. This is also not helped by slow turning movements and unresponsive controls.The AI is also annoying as you try to get it to do something specific and it ends up doing something else entirely.Overall This game was infuriating to play but when it slowed down and placed into much tighter and smaller areas the game really shines but it doesn't make up for the rest of the game.

												Abe's Oddysee is a masterpiece of satire, dark humour and social commentary. One of the few video games to tackle serious real-world issues, Oddysee shines a darkly comedic yet sickly light on the cruelties of factory farming, as well as the exploitation of native cultures and wildlife by corporate greed. The game deals with the dichotomy of industrial and spiritual world views, and places us into a violent, weird and odd world. Just like our own.While these meanings and intentions are confirmed and stem from Oddworld's brainchild Lorne Lanning, all of this is likely lost on most of Oddworld's audience. It certainly was lost on me when I played it as a small child. However, Oddworld Inhabitants provided an exciting, intruiging and challenging experience in Oddysee whether or not the meanings were decoded. And later on, when the messages become more prevalent, it simply gives us more to talk about, and furthers the cause of games as effective, communicative art.Overall, Abe's Oddysee is a great game with a compelling setting and story. Exoddus is a brilliant follow-up, with more of the same. Both highly recommended and unexpectedly intelligent gems.

												I have this game on GOG and on Steam and couldn't recommend it highly enough. It doesn't suffer from a lot of the issues other games from its time may normally suffer from and the majority of the game has aged very well. I believe it's aged so well because of how far ahead of its time it was and of course, the amount of time and love that was put into it. I have beaten this game numerous times on Playstation and I even beat it once with 100% completion, which was no easy task, but it was a lot of fun and more rewarding than achievements in many more modern games.The political undertones within Abe's Oddysee are by no means subtle but they are done so well and clearly weren't just shoehorned in; this game and its story were all built with meaning everywhere. The message is found within it and not the other way around. It's a great message with meaningful characters that could easily have felt generic and certainly could have been more two dimensional like many games at the time. Keep in mind - this is before we even touch the surface of the gameplay. This game is a work of art in that respect as well. The game design is very tightly knit. It's so obvious that the developer loved this game and poured hundreds of hours into ensuring it had a fine layer of polish in every aspect of its design. Your motive is clear from a story standpoint and from a gameplay standpoint. You can almost always immediately see what needs to be done and any thought process required for figuring something out always ends with an intutive solution and never leaves you shaking your head in frustration or disbelief. This game is incredible and at its price point, it's a crime not to already own it; don't get me started on what I think if you're still wondering if you should buy it. I would recommend this to almost everyone but it's certainly not a casual game. If you do NOT like difficulty BUT possess patience then I STILL recommend this game to you.If you don't mind getting stuck and find joy in figuring things out and in continued success in a slightly uphill battle then this game is absolutely for you!If you think you're a boss at games and that difficulty is something you've no intentions of experiencing then prepare to meet it for the first time. This game can be tough but it's a good kind of tough.You know how a good medium rare steak is utterly delicious but requires you to be paitent and chew it a bit?Abe's Oddysee puts that steak to shame because it's got even more seasoning, flavor, and doesn't cost $12 dollars for just a few bites of gameplay.Add this to your library today - unless you're going to play New 'n' Tasty, which DOES include this original as well!If you need help getting this running correctly then check in the community section or do some googling. You just need to a download a config file, open in notepad, make some changes to it and you're on your way! It took me about three minutes. 10/10 from me and I RARELY hand one of those out!Also - I personally recommend a controller for most platformers and I'm the king of platformers.
